018package org.opengis.util;
019
020import java.util.Optional;
021import java.lang.reflect.Type;
022import org.opengis.annotation.UML;
023
024import static org.opengis.annotation.Specification.*;
025import static org.opengis.annotation.Obligation.MANDATORY;
026
027
028/**
029 * A local name that references an object type is some schema.
030 * Can be used as the {@linkplain RecordType#getTypeName() name of a record type},
031 * the {@linkplain org.opengis.feature.FeatureType#getName() name of a feature type},
032 * the {@linkplain org.opengis.metadata.quality.Measure#getValueType() name of data quality result type}
033 * or the {@linkplain MemberName#getAttributeType() name of a field (or member) type} among other usages.
034 *
035 * <h2>Mapping to classes in the Java language</h2>
036 * It is sometimes useful to establish a bidirectional mapping between {@code TypeName} and Java {@link Class}.
037 * For types defined by an OGC/ISO standard, the type name should be the
038 * {@linkplain org.opengis.annotation.UML#identifier() UML identifier}
039 * in the "OGC" {@linkplain #scope() namespace}.
040 * That namespace is consistent with the
041 * <a href="https://schemas.opengis.net/definitions/1.1.0/dataType.xml">data type URN standard values</a>,
042 * also shown below for information purpose.
043 *
044 * <table class="ogc">
045 *   <caption>Mapping from Java classes to type names</caption>
046 *   <tr><th>Java class</th>                                   <th>Scoped type name</th>            <th class="sep">Data type URN standard values</th></tr>
047 *   <tr><td>{@link java.lang.Boolean}</td>                    <td>{@code OGC:Boolean}</td>         <td class="sep">urn:ogc:def:dataType:OGC:1.1:boolean</td></tr>
048 *   <tr><td>{@link java.lang.Integer}</td>                    <td>{@code OGC:Integer}</td>         <td class="sep">urn:ogc:def:dataType:OGC:1.1:nonNegativeInteger</td></tr>
049 *   <tr><td>{@link java.lang.Float}</td>                      <td>{@code OGC:Real}</td>            <td class="sep"></td></tr>
050 *   <tr><td>{@link java.lang.Double}</td>                     <td>{@code OGC:Real}</td>            <td class="sep"></td></tr>
051 *   <tr><td>{@link java.math.BigDecimal}</td>                 <td>{@code OGC:Decimal}</td>         <td class="sep"></td></tr>
052 *   <tr><td>{@link java.lang.String}</td>                     <td>{@code OGC:CharacterString}</td> <td class="sep">urn:ogc:def:dataType:OGC:1.1:string</td></tr>
053 *   <tr><td>{@link org.opengis.util.InternationalString}</td> <td>{@code OGC:FreeText}</td>        <td class="sep"></td></tr>
054 *   <tr><td>{@link java.util.Locale}</td>                     <td>{@code OGC:PT_Locale}</td>       <td class="sep"></td></tr>
055 *   <tr><td>{@link java.time.ZonedDateTime}</td>              <td>{@code OGC:DateTime}</td>        <td class="sep"></td></tr>
056 *   <tr><td>{@link java.net.URI}</td>                         <td>{@code OGC:URI}</td>             <td class="sep">urn:ogc:def:dataType:OGC:1.1:anyURI</td></tr>
057 *   <tr><td>{@link org.opengis.metadata.Metadata}</td>        <td>{@code OGC:MD_Metadata}</td>     <td class="sep"></td></tr>
058 * </table>
059 *
060 * Implementation should define explicitly the mapping to Java classes by overriding the {@link #toJavaType()} method.
061 * It avoids the need to assume any particular convention.
062 *
063 * @author  Bryce Nordgren (USDA)
064 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (IRD)
065 * @version 3.1
066 * @since   2.1
067 *
068 * @see org.opengis.util.Type#getTypeName()
069 * @see RecordType#getTypeName()
070 * @see NameFactory#createTypeName(NameSpace, CharSequence)
071 */
072@UML(identifier="TypeName", specification=ISO_19103)
073public interface TypeName extends LocalName {
074    /**
075     * Returns the local name of the type as a {@code String}.
076     * The local name is the name without namespace, for example {@code "Integer"}.
077     *
078     * <h4>Fully qualified name</h4>
079     * The {@linkplain #toFullyQualifiedName() fully qualified name} may use different separator between path
080     * components depending what the name represents. For example if this {@code TypeName} is part of an URN,
081     * then it will use the {@code ':'} separator as in {@code "[schema]:[type]"}.
082     * But if this {@code TypeName} is the name of a class,
083     * then the fully qualified name will use the {@code '.'} separator as in {@code "[package].[class]"}.
084     *
085     * @return the local name of the type.
086     */
087    @Override
088    @UML(identifier="aName", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19103)
089    String toString();
090
091    /**
092     * Returns the Java type represented by this name.
093     * For example, the {@code "OGC:Integer"} type name may be mapped to the {@link Integer} Java class.
094     * The mapping may be defined by the convention documented in class javadoc, but not necessarily.
095     * Implementations can use their own convention.
096     *
097     * @departure integration
098     *   Added for allowing implementations to define their own mapping
099     *   to a class in the Java programming language.
100     *
101     * @return the Java type (usually a {@link Class}) for this type name.
102     *
103     * @see org.opengis.util.Type#toJavaType()
104     *
105     * @since 3.1
106     */
107    default Optional<Type> toJavaType() {
108        return Optional.empty();
109    }
110}
